abstract.para: The topic gives instructions on how to change the default passphrase after deploying the encrypted image.

warning.title: The system is not secured
warning.para: The system is not secured. Thus, do not store any sensitive data in it until the disk reencryption is complete.

note.title: The step is not needed if you deployed your system using &jeosfirstboot;
note.para: &jeosfirstboot; prompts for a new passphrase during the deployment phase. After you enter it, the system is reencrypted automatically, thus no further action is needed.

topic.para: &productname; encrypted images are delivered with a default LUKS passphrase. To secure your system, make sure that you change it after the system is deployed. To do so, proceed as described below. Perform the steps in the same shell session.

step.para: Import the needed functions to your shell:
Identify the underlying LUKS device and define further used variables:
Check if the image is already reencrypted.
Detect if the file root/.luks.header is in initramfs:
If the file does not exist, the disk is not reencrypted and you can skip the following step.
If the file does exist, compare its content with the output of the following command:
step.screen: &prompt.root;cryptsetup luksHeaderBackup "$luks_dev" --header-backup-file current_header sha256sum current_header | cut -f1 -d" "; rm -f current_header
step.para: If the output of the two commands differ, the disk has been reencrypted and you can skip the procedure. If the output is the same, proceed to the next step.
Create a key file with a new passphrase. Use a strong passphrase with at least 10 characters.
PATH_TO_DEFAULT is a path to the /run/.kiwi_reencrypt.keyfile key file with the default passphrase. PATH_TO_NEW is a path to the key file with your new passphrase.
